subject: Art
title: Color & Emotion
description: How different colors trigger psychological and emotional responses.

hook.text: Hospital walls are rarely red. Fast-food logos are rarely blue. These aren't accidents ‚Äî colors trigger emotions, and designers weaponize this knowledge every day.

buildup.text: Red: passion, urgency, danger. Blue: calm, trust, sadness. Yellow: happiness, energy, caution. Green: nature, growth, balance. Purple: luxury, mystery, creativity. Orange: warmth, enthusiasm, fun.

discovery.text: These associations are partly cultural and partly biological. Red raises heart rate (biological). White means purity in the West but mourning in some Eastern cultures (cultural). Context matters.

twist.text: Saturation and value change the emotion dramatically. Bright red = excitement. Dark red = elegance. Pale red (pink) = sweetness. The hue alone doesn't tell the whole story.

climax.text: Picasso's Blue Period uses desaturated blues to evoke melancholy. His Rose Period shifts to warm pinks and oranges for tenderness. The color IS the emotion.

punchline.text: Colors don't just look different. They feel different. Choose them for their emotional payload.

quiz.question: Why might the emotional association of a color differ between cultures?
options: Colors look different in different countries
Cultural context shapes color symbolism differently
